THE LORDCHANCELLOR.(previous oiisReference:Cabinet SI(23), Con-elusion 2.)1. The Prime Minister informed his colleagues that, to his great regret, Lord Cave had resignedthe office of Lord Chancellor on grounds ofill-health. The Attorney-General had acceptedthe vacancy caused by the Lord Chancellor1sresignation. The present Solicitor-General(Sir Thomas Inskip) had accepted to becomeAttorney-General but would not be a member ofthe Cabinet. Mr P.B. Merriman, K.C., had accepted the post of Solicitor-General. Theabove appointments had received the King*assent. (See also Conclusion 8g)At the request of his colleagues thePrime Minister undertook to write to Lord Cavean expression of their deep regret and sympathy. AFGHANISTAN. 1 S-* -The- Sec ret ary- of--State fox Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet that he had had a conversa-(previous previous reference: tion with King Amanullah and another with his cabinet 11(28), Con- Foreign Secretary. He had learned fromelusion 4.)reliable sources that the King's visit to thiscountry had made a great impression on KingAmanullah himself and on his entourage, with,perhaps, one exception. In the course of an hour's conversation the Afghan Foreign minister had ashed for trade facilities: the trainingof Afghan Officers, which Sir Austen Chamberlainhad undertaken to give: assistance in the formof munitions, in regard to which Sir austen chamberlain had warned him of the world opinion and the strong British opinion in favour of disarmament, but,, subject to that, had expressedthe hope of rendering some assistance; andhad handed in proposals regarding a State Bankwhich were under examination by the Treasury.The Secretary of State informed the Cabinetthat he was about to circulate a Memorandumon his interview. IRAQ,.The AkhwanRaids.(previous eusReference:Cabinet 13(28), Con-concluslon 5.)3. The Secretary of State for the colonies informed the Cabinet that the principal danger in the present situation between Iraq andIbn Saud was that King Peisal might encourageretaliation among his people. He thought,however, that Sir Henry Dobbs had the situationwell in hand, and a British representative also had the frontier Tribes well under control.Mr Amery*s impression was that Ibn Saud had**tear to discotfrage raids. For example, oneraid which had assembled on the Trans J ordaniaside had fallen back, apparently as the resultof Ibn Saud's efforts. The present difficulty was to establish contact with Ibn Saud. TheBritish Resident in the Persian Gulf was underthe impression that Ibn Saud was approachingthat side and wished to have an Interview withhim himself, but the Colonial Office were endeavouring, in accordance with the wishes ofthe Cabinet, to arrange that Sir Gilbert Claytonshould meet Ibn Saud.The Secretary of State for Air reportedthat no raid had taken place since February,which was regarded by the Air Officer commanding in Iraq as reassuring. He felt it was of greatimportance, if Ibn Saud was found to be in a friendly frame of mind, to make peace as soonas possible, and our emissary, whoever he was,should know exactly what was intended.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairsurged that the instructions to our emissaryshould be considered, and that,before negotia-tions were allowed to break down on such aquestion as the establishment of frontier forts,the Cabinet should be given an opportunity for discussion.This view met with general support fromthe Cabinet. The Secretary of State for the Coloniesrecalled that a few weeks ago the Imam of thePreviousReference: Yemen had made an aggression against the AdenCabinet 52(27), Con- Protectorate and had kidnapped two Sheikhs,elusion 9(b) .)In consequence it had been necessary (in accord-ance with the Cabinet decision on December 1,1926 (Cabinet 61 (26) Conclusion 6), to retaliate, and the Royal Air Force had bombed the Imam's troops intermittently. The result was that the Imam had now climbed down, had sent back the captured Chiefs, and was suingfor a truce and asking for discussions.Trie Secretary of State for Air urged thatit was most important to make peace in this region while the opportunity was open, and he hoped that no time would be lost in decidinghow much of the Aden Protectorate it wasnecessary to insist on.The Cabinet concurred in this view and expressed satisfaction at this further vlndica-tion of the policy of using the Royal AirForce against Native forces. CHINA.Withdrawalof Forces.(previous previous reference:Cabinet 15(88), Con-elusion 2.)5. The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs reported that the Nanking negotiations had broken down, but apparently on a very narrowis sue. He was accordingly trying to save thesituation, and was in communication with SirMiles Lampson on the subject.In the meantime a telegram had beenreceived from the Naval Commander-in-chief(No.979, dated March 25th) pointing out thatthe failure to reach a settlement over theNanking incident was likely to result inviolent repercussions all over China, especiallyin the Yangtse Valley, and expressing the view(i) that in consequence the departure of theThird Destroyer Flotilla in April was inadvis-able; (ii) that any further reduction of the china Fleet or the Shanghai Defence Force was out of the question", and (iii) that it wasnecessary to retain the guard on shore at nanking.The Cabinet agreed That, notwithstanding the authority given by the Cabinet regarding thereduction of forces in Ohina, theNaval Commander-in-Chief shouldhave discretion (subject to theconcurrence of the British Ministerat Peking and, in the case of thegarrison at Nanking or other land forces, of the General OfficerCommandlng-in-Chief) to retain anylorces destined for withdrawalwhich he deemed necessary for the fulfilment of his responsibilities. In addition to the Memorandum underconsideration at the previous Meeting, theCabinet had before them telegrams circulatedimmediately before the Meeting indicating thatLegal Officers of the Irish Free State were due in London the same morning to confer withLegal Officers of the Treasury and dominions office.The Cabinet took note of a statement by the Secretary of State for Dominion affairs to the above effect.At the outset of the Meeting the PrimeMinister had read to his colleagues a letterfrom Viscount Cave on the subject of the judgment of the Judicial Committee of the privy Council which the Lord Chancellor was prepared to publish if and when the Cabinetthought fit oThe Cabinet, while warmly conscious ofthe spirit in which the Lord Chancellorsletter was written, expressed the hope thatit would be unnecessary for them to avail themselves of his offer and had decided notto do so except in the last resort, and not until the letter had been shown privately tosome of the parties mainly interested in thepolitical aspects of this question. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs(Paper CoP.-95 (28)) asking the Cabinet tosupport Mr Somerville's Bill to amend the empire settlement Act, 1922, subject to certain neces-sary amendments set forth in the Memorandum.A copy of the Bill was attached to the Memorandumshowing the amendments which the Secretary ofState deemed necessary, the principal of whichare:-(i) To allow of Agricultural TrainingSchemes for the purpose of trainingmen in this country for agricultureat home as well as for overseas.(ii) To enable the dependants of menwho are being trained under such schemes to draw allowances duringthe period of training.(iii) To enable the Secretary of state to contribute up to the whole costof agricultural training schemes under his control or administered by a Government Department, insteadof, as at present, not more than half the cost of any scheme.Alternative proposals were madefor contributions towards TrainingSchemes not under Government control.The Cabinet also had before them a Memo-randum by the Minister of Agriculture and Fish-eries (Paper 0.P.-96 (28)) opposing the proposal that powers be given to the Secretary of Statefor Dominion Affairs to establish centres forthe purpose of training men in this countryfor employment in home agriculture.Shortly before the Meeting a Note by theChancellor of the Exchequer (Paper C.P.-98 (28))was circulated, covering a Memorandum by theTreasury, suggesting that the Government shouldnot accept the Private Bill on the subject norendeavour to adapt it to their plans before announced to them. The Cabinet must reservefall and unfettered liberty, andno obligation should be enteredinto with the Promoters of theBill. 10. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Attorney-General covering a draft Admin-iatration of Justice Bill (Paper C.P.-97 (28)).The main provisions of this Bill are as followsPart I. Re-organisation of the DistrictProbate Registries.Part II. Administrative provisions,mainly of minor importance,designed to improve themachinery of the Courts.Part III.The strengthening of theJudicial Committee of the privy Council in regard tothe hearing of Indian Appeals,provision being made for theappointment of two qualifiedmembers with a salary of 2,000, charged on the consolidated Fund, theirretirement being at the ageof 72, with a pension of 1,000 per annum. A further provision i3 contained thatthe salary may be increased,if the Indian government think, fit, by a sum notexceeding 2,000. provision was also included for removing the limit on the number of qualified Dominion Judgeswho may become members ofthe Privy Council.Parts IV and V, dealing with details.The Attorney-General undertook, at therequest of the Cabinet, to enquire as to why theretiring age for the Indian Judges was fixed at72.The Attorney-General informed the Cabinetthat an amendment would be required in Clause 10of the draft to avoid interference with the powerof sealing up Royal Wills.The Cabinet agreed To approve the Administration ofJustice Bill, subject to suchminor drafting alterations as might be necessary.?R"E ADMINIS-TPATI0N OPJUSTICE BILL. THE WEST AFRICANREGIMENT.Disbandme.it of.(previous reference:Cabinet 60(27), Con-clusion 5.)lljThe Cabinet bad before them a Memorandumby the Secretary of State for War notifyingthat, resulting out of consideration by theCommittee of Imperial Defence on November 1,1927, after communication with the Secretaryof State for the Colonies, the Army Council had decided on the disbandment of the West AfricanRegiment and that it was his intention to takethe necessary steps to carry this decision intoeffect (Paper G.P.-65 (28)).The Secretary of State for War informed the Cabinet that the Colonial Office had notbeen able to provide for the maintenance ofthis Regiment on Colonial Votes, and in conse-quence the Army Council, with great regret,felt that it was unavoidable to disband it.The Cabinet took note of and approved the Army Council9sdecisions e% f c15 D12. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Secretary of State for War (Paper C.P.-99 (28)) covering the Army and Air Force"(Annual) Eill. In his Memorandum the Secretaryof State for War proposed an alteration of theAct in regard to the death penalty, and statedthat, after careful consideration with his military Advisers, he had come to the conclu---sion that it cannot be held to be essentialto the maintenance of discipline and moralthat the death penalty should be retained for any military offences except mutiny inpeace and war, and treachery, cowardice anddesertion, including leaving a post or guardon active service. The amendments to Clause 4of the Bill have the effect of abolishing the penalty for all other military offences .The Cabinet were informed that all theService Departments were agreed on this Bill.The First Lord of the Admiralty statedthat, if there was any desire for an amendmentof the Navy Discipline Act, he was prepared toIntroduce a Bill to that effect at short notice,and he anticipated no difficulty in passing it.Until that was done there would be a slightdiscrepancy between the law of the death penalty for the Navy, on the one hand, and theArmy and Air Force on the other.The Cabinet approved the Army andAir Force (Annual) Bill in the formattached to Paper C.P.-99 (28). 9r (* * J "JREGISTRATION 13. The attention of the Cabinet was drawn(BIRTHS DEATHSAND MARRIAGES) to the Registration (Births, Deaths and Marriages)'BILL.Bill, to be Introduced by a Private Member0(3^)1^. (Captain Gunston) on Friday, April 20th.The Minister of Health informed theCabinet that this Bill had originally been drafted in his own Department, but he had notbeen able to Include it in the GovernmentTsProgramme. It had now been Introduced as aPrivate Member's Bill. The object of the bill was gradually to place the remuneration ofRegistrars on a proper footing. At presentthe regulations governing their salaries werefull of anomalies, being based on a Bill passed in 1836.The Cabinet agreed That the Minister of health should have authority toencourage the Bill and, without giving any positive undertaking,should indicate that the Govern-ment would grant facilities Ifthe exigencies of parliamentary time should permit. The President of the Board of trade informed the Cabinet that he had had a satis-factory interview with the Chairman and deputy chairman of the Pood Council. They had under-taken to invite the Pood Commission to presenta Report on the lines discussed at theprevious Meeting of the Cabinet. The publica-tion of this Report would be delayed until thePresident or the Board of Trade had answereda Question in the House of Commons indicating the intention of the Government to take legal powers, if necessary, to compel the productionof information. The Pood Commission wouldthen do their best to obtain the Informationthey required under the tin-eat of the powers which they expected to be conferred upon them.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,March 28, 1928.
